Award.AbstractNarration:
Around 1960 Erdos and Renyi undertook a systematic study of what they called a randomly evolving (re) graph. Starting with an empty graph on n vertices, at each discrete moment a new edge is added, its position being chosen uniformly at random among the re alternatives. The basic question is what does the random graph look like after some m edges have been inserted? They were able to give a remarkable concise asymptotic description of this evolving graph, and opened the gates to a flood of research on this and many other random graph processes. Today random graph theory is a thriving area of probabilistic combinatorics that has found many applications in statistical physics (percolation), physical chemistry and theoretical computer science. Quite remarkably, random graph models have become indispensable for the analysis of probabilistic models of growing information (social) networks. The proposer will continue his work on a model of random graph (network) in which the new edges (links) tend to join the more "social" vertices (nodes), those with higher than average number of already existing links. However simple-minded, mathematical models of such graphs have a potential to become useful quantitative tools in the statistical analysis of real-life networks and they have proved to be valuable in other areas, such as polymerization theory. The proposal includes problems on other classes of random graphs, such as directed graphs in which each edge has a direction, chordal diagrams--a key notion in knot theory, threshold graphs in which the nodes are assigned weights and the edges develop only between the nodes with the total weight exceeding a threshold value, and random graphs in which each vertex degree exceeds 3. (The latter condition is basically necessary for the random graph to have a Hamilton cycle.) He will also use random graphs with restricted degrees to analyze solvability of a random system of Boolean equations. This problem belongs to a rapidly developing area of combinatorial probability and theoretical computer science that has turned out to be receptive to strikingly diverse approaches, including models and methods of statistical physics.

This research may contribute to development of theoretical models and mathematical techniques that can be used by researchers in various areas who confront a challenge to describe (to predict) the structural behavior of huge networks based on assumptions regarding rules of local (pairwise) interactions between the individual nodes. The proposer will use this research program to engage his graduate students and to guide their studies toward completion of their PhD degrees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A classic example of a combinatorial structure is a network (a graph), described as a set of nodes (vertices) connected to their neighbors by links (arcs, edges). The networks (graphs) have long being used as abstract mathematical descriptions of real-life social and/or technological networks. In 1959 -1960 Erdos and Renyi began studying a mathematical model of a graph with many vertices that slowly emerges in time, as one link after another is inserted between two randomly selected nodes. However idealized, this model captured a combinatorial complexity of the real networks that are poorly connected at the inception and become more and more tight as more and more pairwise links appear in a chaotic fashion, without a grand designer watching over. Erdos and Renyi discovered a remarkable mathematical phenomenon: for a long time the evolving graph remains split into many small connected components, and then during a relatively short time period the network undergoes a dramatic transition which results in appearance of a giant connected subnetwork (subgraph) that contains a positive fraction of all vertices. This pioneering advance started avalanche of research aimed at elucidating deeper feautures of the phase transition phenomenon and tracking down the likely changes in the graph structure beyond the birth of the giant component.

Among the outcomes of this project is a detailed analysis of a much-less studied counterpart of the evolving network in which the pairwise links have a direction. Here the notion of a component morphs into two deal notions, of a sink-set and a source-set. We were able to find the distribution of the parameters of the giant strong component, i.e. the subnetwork in which there exists a directed path from an arbitrary vertex to any other vertex. This advance opens a way for a study of a rather complex phenomenon of sudden birth of a "core" of the directed graph, a maximal subgraph with in/out-degrees exceeding given bounds, a long-standing problem in random networks theory.

We also studied  a large a network evolving under a preferential attachment rule (or the popularity effect): while the links are inserted one at a time, the vertices chosen as endpoints previously are more likely to be chosen going forward. These processes have become well known since Barabasi and Albert introduced the first such model to explain a ``scale-free'' vertex degree distribution observed empirically in various real-world networks. In this scheme the vertex set grows in time, each new vertex attaching itself randomly to existing vertices, with probabilities proportional to their current ``popularity'' (degree). Previously we studied a counterpart of Erdos-Renyi graph process in which the links appear with probability proportional to the product of the endnodes degrees. In the current project we analyzed a directed version, establishing a threshold of this popularity-dependence for asymptotic similarity to an absolutely chaotic evolution, blind to the current popularity of the vertices.

Motivated by problems in statistical mechanics, we analyzed the combinatorial-probabilistic properties of the subgraphs spanning (covering) a large graph. In particular, as an extension of the classic results, due to Heilmann-Lieb and Godsil, we found a sharp formula for counting the spanning subgraphs formed by "polymers", those with vertex degrees having range {0,1,2}.

Among other results, we should mention our study of phase-transition phenomenon in solvability of a random system of linear (Boolean) equations. We found that such a system is very likely to be solvable (unsolvable) if the ratio of the number of equations and the number of variables falls below (exceeds) a certain explicit value, dependent on the number of variables in each equation.
